awd_titl_txt: GEM: Experimental Identification of Plasma Wave Modes in Vicinity of Kelvin-Helmholtz (KH) Vortices and in Plasma 'Mixing' Regions in Low Latitude Boundary Layer
awd_abstract_narration:
This project focuses on understanding the dynamics of the boundary between the solar wind and the Earth's magnetic field. The interactions between electromagnetic waves and charged particles that result in heating of the particles is a universal process, but the near-Earth space is currently the only plasma physics laboratory where the physics can be studied with in-situ measurements in naturally existing scales. Examining this problem in the magnetosphere will provide insight into the solar coronal heating problem. This can benefit the larger space- and astrophysics community beyond the immediate field of magnetospheric physics. The PI is a tenured female physics professor and the project will fund and involve ERAU undergraduate students in summer research program and fund a female Ph.D student, for 3 years. 

In order to enhance understanding of the origin of the cross-scale non-adiabatic ion and electron heating at the Low Latitude Boundary Layer (LLBL) from magnetohydrodynamics (MHD) to ion to electron scales, plasma waves will be identified above ion cyclotron frequency extending to electron scales. These will be examined during 'mixed' intervals with and without simultaneous Kelvin Helmholtz (KH) activity, and study the possible free sources of energy in particle distributions, and in microscopic electron and ion velocity gradients that can for the first time be resolved with the data from Magnetosphere Multi-Scale (MMS) mission. The objectives of this proposal are to address what the observed higher frequency waves in the LLBL are, what their characteristics and relation to ambient plasma conditions are, and what their role is in ion and electron heating. While the proposed work addresses the micro-scale physics, which is currently neglected in global MHD codes, it will help understand the interdependence between fluid scale KH and kinetic scale waves as well as how these kinetic scale waves modify the ambient plasma properties. The ambient plasma properties are crucial in determining the reconnection efficiency and solar wind-magnetosphere coupling. The study is therefore highly relevant for understanding the physics that needs to be taken into account for developing better global space weather and magnetospheric models.

por.por_cntn:
The Intellectual Merit:  Plasmas -often called the 4th state of matter- fill 99 percent of the visible universe.  Understanding the physics of the plasma stability, heating and transport is fundamentally important in order to one day achieve thermonuclear fusion, capable for providing humanity plentiful of clean energy from water. Presently the near Earth space is  the only place in the universe where we can study plasmas in their naturally existing scales with multi-point, in-situ, measurements. Sun emits constantly solar wind, a relatively cold plasma but with a high kinetic energy. When this plasma encounters planetary obstacles it gets rapidly heated, but the detailed physics of this heating has been a long-standing mystery.  

In this project we have utilized data from 4 spacecraft MMS satellites to study how giant (12,000-36,000 km in wavelength) Kevin-Helmholtz waves (i.e. space hurricanes)  and associated secondary smaller scale waves (tornadoes) heat the plasma at the boundary of the Earth's magnetic shield. We have developed new techniques how to identify these space hurricanes and calculate how fast they can grow. We also perfomed a statistical study of the space tornadoes within these large-scale hurricanes. Our results show that KH waves are frequently present, both at high-and low latitudes of our magnetic shield. Our study also shows that when KH waves are present, there is more ion scale waves (100 to 500 km in wavelength) present that can heat the plasma more effectively. This is because KH waves, can twist the magnetic field like a "candy-wrapper". This twisting can result in magnetic reconnection about 18,000 km above and below of the eye of the hurricane, which will mix plasma of hot magnetospheric and cold solar wind origin. This results in unstable distribution of ions which gives rise to free energy to create the smaller scale waves that can then interact with electrons and ions, heating them effectively. As a new existing puzzle, we also found that these space hurricanes also contain extremely high-energy ions and electrons. These particles can't be accelerated to such high-energies by these smaller scale waves so understanding their detailed acceleration will be an important topic for future study. 

The  Broader Impacts: 

Teaching and Mentoring: Project has enabled PI, a female Physics Professor, to continue her research program in ERAU. In particular, the  project has enabled PI to develop research projects utilizing spacecraft data and numerical simulations for 15 ERAU undergraduate students in Space Physics class and for 11 students in Space Weather class, and for 4 Ph.D students in graduate class, Space Plasma Physics. Project has fully supported a Ph.D stipend and tuition for 5 years for ERAU female graduate student who graduated in Spring 2022, and partial support for a male graduate student, expected to graduate in Fall 2023. Thus the project has improved engagement and retention of underpresented groups in STEM-fields.  project has supported students' and PI's travel to American Geophysical Union (AGU) Fall meeting , MMS meetings and to NSF GEM meeting, and supported PI travel to COSPAR meeting.  Thus the project has enabled professional development and networking of the underpresented  groups in STEM fields. 

Dissemination of New Knowledge: PI has shared project outcomes of exciting results in her twitter page and has been enaged with public outreach activities: the Women of Science Events and speaker series at ERAU, as well as in Walkabout the Galaxy podcast organized by UCF.  PI has given 19 invited talks/seminars of the project results at different conferences and universities, including the plenary tutorial at the NSF sponsored Geospace Modeling Workshop in June 23rd, 2022: Influence of the Kelvin-Helmholtz Instability on the Plasma Entry, Transport and Energization at the Magnetospheric Boundary Layers. Undergraduate and graduate students have presented their work at ERAU Discovery day and at teh AGU, MMS, and GEM meetings. PI organized with students and other scientist and ERAU personnel MMS 7 year launch anniversary workshop at ERAU in May, 2022. In this workshop students learned about  MMS data-analysis using SPEDAS in a tutorial given by E. Grimes. Project has resulted  in 11 peer-reviewed publications in scientific journals, with at least 2 more publications in process that will be first authored by students. Thus the project has engaged both general public and scientific audience.

The study has addressed particle heating across the shocked solar wind and magnetospheric plasma, which is driven by mechanisms  fluid (>1000 km), ion (< 500 km) and electron (< 10 km) scales. The cross-scale energy transport between these scales is a  fundamental problem of plasma physics. Wave-particle interactions and resulting plasma heating is an universal process, but the near-Earth space is currently the only plasma physics laboratory where these interactions can be studied in naturally existing scales. Thus the project has resulted in new knowledge, highly relevant also for plasma physics, not solely for space physics.
